Expectation1: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation1: The passenger emergency alarm has been activated due to a medical emergency in the train.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I glanced at my watch, heart pounding. My shift as a subway operator had just ended, and I rushed to the polling station, determined to cast my vote before closing. As I handed over my ID, the election official frowned, explaining a registration mismatch. I’d have to fill out a provisional ballot form, and the station would close in ten minutes. My hands shook as I took the form, but just then, my phone buzzed—an emergency alert from the subway control room. A passenger had collapsed on my train, and the emergency alarm was blaring. Protocol demanded I return immediately to assist, ensuring passenger safety. But the official was waiting, pen in hand, expecting me to complete the paperwork now or lose my chance to vote. I felt torn in two, the weight of civic duty pressing against my responsibility for the passengers who might need me. My mind raced, caught between the urgent call of my job and the once-a-year chance to have my voice heard.
